Question:
Does the site have an individual identified as the POC for
instrument reprocessing?
Does the POC have record of training/competency in instrument reprocessing (reviewer should visually verify)?

Does the site have an instrument reprocessing SOP available
(reviewer should visually verify)?
Comments and Recommendations

Were the instruments rinsed or wiped off with a damp gauze
to remove gross contamination immediately after the case?

Is there a process to flag and communicate instrument
problems (e.g., dull scissors or non-locking clamp)?

Was prolonged instrument soaking (>10 minutes) avoided?
(soaking instruments prior to cleaning is not recommended, however, if it is done,
it should be <10 minutes

If soaking was used, was the use of saline, chlorine, or
disinfectant avoided? (plain water or detergent (soap) are ok; please note that
soaking in any chlorine solution, a common procedure in the past, should not be
done)

Were instruments left open (i.e., jaws not clamped shut) during
and after pre-cleaning? (If instruments are clamped shut, closed surfaces and
hinges cannot be cleaned which allows organic material to dry and become stuck)

Were instruments transported from point of use to cleaning
area in a leak-proof, puncture-proof, and covered container?

Were instruments kept moist the entire time between end of
case and cleaning?
Comments and Recommendations

Was appropriate PPE (hair cover, eye/mouth protection,
impermeable gown, gloves, closed shoes) worn during cleaning?

Was a clean container filled with an appropriate amount of water
and detergent to allow complete immersion of the instruments?

Were the instruments cleaned using a soft (nylon) bristle brush
under the surface of the water (to avoid producing aerosols)?
Were all hinged instruments opened during cleaning?

Were instruments immersed or rinsed thoroughly with clean
water after cleaning with the brush? (soft (e.g., distilled) water preferable if
available to prevent deposits and buildup on instruments)

Were instruments closely inspected after cleaning, prior to drying,
to make sure all visible contamination had been removed?

Were instruments cleaned in an area that is adequately
illuminated? (the inspection area should have adequate illumination (natural light
may be adequate,) to see small amounts of contamination)
Were instruments air-dried or dried by hand with a clean, non-linting cloth?

Was the overall flow of instruments in the cleaning area
unidirectional from “dirty” to “clean”

If both reusable and single use instruments are used, is there an
established way these are separated and distinguished from one another?
(Assessor should ask for a description of this process. Single use instruments are
typically marked by the words “single use” or the number '2' with a strike through
it).
Comments and Recommendations

Were instruments checked for proper functioning, and
lubricated as necessary to allow free movement at hinges, prior to packaging?

Are kits assembled to ensure completeness and standard
contents? (sites often have an instrument list posted in the packaging area as a
job aid)

Is the packaging material permeable to the sterilizing agent (e.g.,
steam)? Packaging material examples include: double layer of lint-free dense
woven cloth (≥140 threads/inch2
), unwoven cloth permeable to steam (i.e.,
sterilization wrap), surgical-grade paper (not recycled paper or newspaper), or
rigid reusable sterilization containers.
Does packaging securely enclose items to be sterilized?

Does packaging maintain sterility of contents until opened
(doesn’t easily puncture or allow contamination inside)?

Does every package have an external chemical indicator?
(external chemical indicators show when a package has been exposed to one or
more sterilization parameters such as temperature, pressure, time; external
indicators are used to differentiate processed and non-processed items)

Does every package contain an internal chemical indicator?
(internal chemical indicators show that the instruments themselves, not just the
outside of the package, were exposed to one or more sterilization parameters)
indicators are used to differentiate processed and non-processed items)

Is every package labeled with sterilization date and/or expiry
date, contents (e.g., “vmmc kit”), and load number?
Comments and Recommendations
Is steam sterilization in use? If yes, answer the following:

Has the person responsible for operating the autoclave
received training on how to do so? (Sometimes facility staff, not VMMC staff, run
the autoclave. This question explores presence and type of training they received.
Please check documentation (e.g., training certificate) if available.)

Is cycle temperature either pre-set by load type or, if manually
set, to at least 121⁰C ? Cycle times will vary (3-18 minutes) depending on
temperature (121⁰C - 135⁰C), please refer to manufacturer’s instructions for use, if
available, to check that manually set time is correct for temp.
Are the following cycle parameters recorded in a logbook?

Is the autoclave loaded in a manner to ensure steam contact
and penetration? (not overloaded, packages away from chamber walls, rigid
containers not stacked unless validated by manufacturer for this configuration,
steri-peel packages on edge with multiple packages placed paper-to-plastic, non perforated containers placed on edge)

Correct cycle parameters met? (if pre-set parameters, could
just mean the ‘failure’ indicator did not light up)
indicators are used to differentiate processed and non-processed items)
External indicators appropriately changed?

No visible signs of moisture? (no dampness, droplets, or
puddles on or within a package)
No visible signs of compromised package integrity?

Bowie-Dick test (measures air removal in pre-vacuum autoclaves,
not used in gravity displacement autoclaves; ideally performed
daily)

Biological indicators (please make note how often these are used
(ideally should be daily, but at least weekly)

Is distilled water being used in the autoclave? (most autoclave
manufacturers recommend use of distilled water to avoid mineral deposits which
can decrease useable life of the autoclave)

Over the past 6 months has the distilled water inventory
been maintained to ensure uninterrupted services?

Is there documentation of at least annual routine maintenance
performed by a technician? (if “no” then please ask follow-up question about why
this was not done)

Was the overall flow of instruments in the sterilization area
unidirectional from “non-sterile” to “sterile”?

Are all biologic and chemical indicators within their expiration
dates?

Over the past 6 months has the reprocessing equipment and
supplied inventory been maintained to ensure uninterrupted services?

Over the past 6 months has the reprocessing equipment and
supplied inventory been maintained to ensure uninterrupted services?1
Comments and Recommendations

Is the portion of the transport vehicle where instrument
containers are placed completely enclosed?

Are the containers for sterile and non-sterile instruments
clearly marked?

Is a system in place to track movement of instrument kits
between sites, and know where they are at all times? (for example, to find where
all kits sterilized on x date in cycle number y are located; if one kit from a specific
load is noted to have problems, it will be important to immediately identify all the
other kits that were in the same load).
Comments and Recommendations

Are freshly sterilized instruments allowed to cool to room
temperature before they are used for surgery?

Is a practice of first in first out used to ensure that older kits (by
date of sterilization) are used first?

Is there an inventory monitoring system that tracks the movement
of kits in and out of the storage or sterilization area?
Comments and Recommendations
